description.narrative:
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The proposed intervention is a core support of SEK 190 million 2018-2022 to The Tenure Facility (TF), of which SEK 130 million from the Strategy for Globally Sustainable Economic Development, and SEK 60 million from Strategy for Sustainable Environment, Climate, Oceans and Use of Natural Resources. The contribution is also highly relevant to the Strategy for Human Rights, Democratization and Rule of Law. Close cooperation and coordination is foreseen on the issue of tenure between the three strategies including in the follow up of this intervention.
In addition, the European Commission plans to channel EUR 7 million via Sida in a delegated cooperation agreement for core support. This support is planned for 2019-2021. Therefore the full assessment is written in English.
The TF aims to secure land and forest rights for Indigenous peoples and local communities in the developing world by providing project support to the communities, civil society, and to some extent to governments. Government support and involvement is always required for a project to be accepted.
Sida supported Rights and Resources Initiative’s (RRI) establishment of the TF since its beginnings in 2012-2013 for the development of the initial proposal and program documents. The pilot phase of TF was also managed by RRI, in 2014-2018, with a Sida support of 130 MSEK. In addition, Sida supports RRI with core support, 9 MSEK on average 2013-2017 and 25 MSEK per year 2018-2021.
This proposed intervention will be the first considerable direct support to this new organization. It has approximately the same annual amount as the previous phase, that was channeled through RRI. Thus far, it has received direct funding from the Ford Foundation, 3 MUSD in 2017 and 2018.
Access to land and natural resources for rural poor is often based on customary tenure, which tends to be insecure due to a lack of political, legal and administrative recognition, and contradictions between the formal and informal systems. This leads to a situation of insecurity for these local communities that affects most aspects of life, such as access to and/or security of livelyhoods, including food, water, housing and source of income, political rights to participate in processes that concern the land you live on and the land you have used for generations, the social rights and traditions that relate to the community; how you take decisions, plan your production, etcetera. For the wider society, insecurity of tenure also has negative aspects, since it can limit economic development, spark conflict and lead to deforestation and unsustainable land use – a climate change driver and a cause of flooding, mudslides and loss of ecosystem services.
Collective tenure is often not considered in the legal systems, and insecure collective tenure often concerns forest. Therefore, both RRI and the TF have a focus on forest lands, although grazelands and agricultural lands also can be considered for support.
Fortunately, the global advocacy over the last decades - by RRI and others - for the political and legal recognition of communal land rights for indigenous peoples (IPs) and local communities have resulted in considerable advances and adapted legal frameworks in many countries. However, all this leeway did not give secure tenure on the ground, since there is a void in implementation and in administrative recognition.
The lack of implementation should not automatically be interpreted as a lack of political will or of resources – but often a lack of capacity, information and experience. It is a new field of work for government administration as well as for NGOs and communities. RRI concluded that a special focus on the practical aspects of implementation was needed. The TF offers the following kinds of support (quoted from web page https://thetenurefacility.org/what-we-do/ on 181122)
Scale up implementation of land and forest tenure reform policies and legislation by:– Providing support to establish legitimate tenure rights in areas where traditional communal rights are not formally recognized– Providing support for community mapping, demarcation, and registration efforts– Strengthening the capacity of national organizations to provide land tenure related services to reach disadvantaged and vulnerable groups
Enable governments and communities to test new models, strategies and approaches by:– Testing practical solutions to implementation challenges– Assisting governments and communities to overcome administrative obstacles to land rights recognition and titling– Building capacity of government agencies responsible for titling and protecting indigenous and community rights
About the Tenure Facility organization:
The TF has its headquarters in Stockholm, established in 2017. RRI decided to place the headquarters in Stockholm following their independent analysis. It is registered as a non-profit foundation, insamlingsstiftelse, and subject for control by the Stockholm Province Authority (Länsstyrelsen) in accordance with the Foundation Law, SFS 1994:1220.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Det föreslagna stödet är ett kärnstöd om 190 miljoner SEK 2018-2022 till The Tenure Facility (TF). TF är en internationell organisation med säte i Sverige som verkar för att säkra kollektiva mark och skogsrättigheter för urfolk och lokalsamhällen med syfte att öka deras egenmakt, att kunna skydda sin mark. Detta väntas få som effekt, enligt organisationens Theory of Change, att möjligheterna till livsmedelstrygghet, ekonomisk utveckling, och hållbart nyttjande av naturresurser främjas, samt att konfliktnivån minskar.
Kollektiva markrättigheter har de senaste årtiondena fått ökat erkännande och anpassat lagligt ramverk i många länder. Dessvärre översätts dessa sällan fullt ut i administrativa åtgärder som leder till lagfarter och en tryggare situation. The Tenure Facility skapades för att praktiskt stötta implementeringen av dessa lagar i konkreta projekt. Därigenom byggs kunskap och erfarenhet som the Tenure Facility delar internationellt.
Samarbetsparten är lokalsamhället som eftersträvar kollektiva rättigheter till sin traditionella mark, ofta urfolk. Avtal ingås antingen direkt eller via en administrativ samarbetspart beroende på kapacitet. Ansvarig statlig enhet ska alltid vara involverad i projektformulering och genomförande, eftersom ett mål med projekten också är att staten ska applicera resultatet på nationell nivå. 80% av projekten kommer implementeras i tropiska skogsområden, 20% i övriga landskap, samtliga i utvecklingsländer med fokus på marginaliserade grupper.
Initiativet att bilda the Tenure Facility kom från Rights and Resources Initiative (RRI), en global koalition av NGOs som arbetar för kollektiva markrättigheter. RRI får kärnstöd från Sida sen 2013. Sida gav stöd till Rights and Resources Initiative för konsultation och formulering av TF-konceptet 2012-2013, och för en pilotfas 2014-2017 där konceptet testades i sex länder med ett Sidastöd på 130 miljoner SEK. Utvärderingen som utfördes 2017 av de sex pilotprojekten (Universalia, 2017) var positiv gällande relevans, resultatuppfyllelse och kostnadseffektivitet. Rekommendationerna från utvärderingen var huvudsakligen riktade till och integrerades i den vidare institutionella utvecklingen.
I andra halvan av pilotfasen påbörjades etableringen av organisationen the Tenure Facility med målet att nästa fas skulle genomföras av en fristående institution. Denna process har letts av RRI och följts noggrant av givargruppen, bestående av Sida, Norway's International Climate and Forest Initiative (NICFI, på norska miljödepartementet)/Norad och Ford Foundation. RRI och givarna har följt upp med flera utvärderingar och revisioner. Utifrån dessa har utvecklingsplaner med milstolpar tagits fram för att säkra en transparent och balanserad process. "Internationella Insamlingsstiftelsen för Mark och Skogsrättigheter" - Tenure Facility's juridiska namn - stiftades i januari 2017. Sedan början av 2018 har etableringen letts av the Tenure Facility från sekretariatet Stockholm.
Tenure Facility styrs av en styrelse med upp till 11 medlemmar, varav 4 ingår i den grupp som väljer projekt. Sammansättningen är noga avvägd, med finansiell expertis, såväl som representanter med erfarenhet från stat, civilsamhälle, ursprungsfolk och privata sektorn. Det finns också en rådgivargrupp, där civilsamhälle, ursprungsbefolkningsgrupper och olika internationella organ, så som IFC och FAO, finns representerade. Givarna har separata möten samt har möjlighet att delta i rådgivargruppens möten med styrelsen, men deltar inte i styrelsens beslut eller i urvalet av projekt.
TF är en organisation som skapar kunskap genom att finansiera och lära ifrån implementeringen av projekt. Minst två tredjedelar av budgeten kommer därför gå till projekt. Deras storlek varierar mellan 200 000USD och 2 000 000USD och är upp till tre år långa. TF ingår avtal för varje projekt efter att avtalspartens kapacitet bedömts enligt etablerade kriteria.

participating-org.narrative: Internationella Insamlingsstiftelsen för Mark och Skogsrättigheter

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.

13.b - Promote mechanisms for raising capacity for effective climate change-related planning and management in least developed countries and small island developing States, including focusing on women, youth and local and marginalized communities.

13.b - Främja mekanismer för att höja förmågan till effektiv klimatrelaterad planering och förvaltning i de minst utvecklade länderna, med särskilt fokus på kvinnor, ungdomar samt lokala och marginaliserade samhällen.

15.2 - By 2020, promote the implementation of sustainable management of all types of forests, halt deforestation, restore degraded forests and substantially increase afforestation and reforestation globally.

15.2 - Till 2020 främja genomförandet av hållbart brukande av alla typer av skogar, stoppa avskogningen, återställa utarmade skogar och kraftigt öka nybeskogningen och återbeskogningen i hela världen.

title.narrative: 18/000592 Beslut om insats The Tenure Facility 2018-2022
18/000592 Grant Agreement between Sida and the Tenure Facility

description.narrative: The baseline has been built retrospectively progress made during 2019, will be included in the annual report to be submitted in May 2020. The baseline findings and report as well as the executive directors report containing progress of the Tenure Facility maturing as an organisation, were all presented during the learning exchange in Bogota/Colombia during October 2019. Some of the results included: - Base-line established with data from project partners Sept 2019 - Increased Funding 2018-2020 from donors, USD 13,6 million in 2019 and secured USD 13,6 million for 2020 - Consolidated Secretariat, from 4 fulltime staff to now 13 - Stronger partnerships with government in Liberia, Peru, Indonesia Colombia, Guyana, Mozambique, Mali The monitoring framework, the TF results framework with indicators and targets as well as the risk register, are still not final and Norad are coordinating the donor response. The was all discussed during the last meeting with Tenure Facility, Norad and Sida in March 2020 (minutes in Dox).The monitoring framework is set to be approved by donors by June 2020. Sidas input mainly concentrated on environment and livelihoods integration (see meeting minutes). According to TF, tenure is their niche and their support to livelihood efforts is through their partners strategies and efforts. The first offical results from the contribution are expected to be included in the annual report from 2019.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
